Destin, Another method to stop the bullet would be to use more flashes, all firing at a lower flash power. No matter what power a flash is set to, camera flashes always fire at the same luminosity, they adjust their apparent brightness by lengthening the flash duration. The flash duration of your Canon 580ex II is 1/1000th of a second at full power (1/1) and at 1/4 power it is 1/4000th, and so on. Four flashes firing at 1/4 power equal the "brightness" of one firing at full power, but the flash duration is shorter, potentially freezing the bullet. Technically you could be crazy and have 128 flashes firing at 1/128 power and have a 1/35,000th second flash duration, but then you might as well buy a dedicated high speed flash! You should do a high speed video about the nature of how camera flash works! It's very interesting.

I think modern cartridges use powders which are made from varying mixtures of nitrocellulose, nitroglycerine, and a few other nitrogen based compounds, depending on the type of gun it's designed for. They're called smokeless powders since they produce almost no smoke in comparison to black powder ("gunpowder") which is still used in antique muskets that would probably blow up if you used smokeless in them.

@SynchronizedMedie nope, they use gun powder. The actual name is kordite, when it "explodes" it creates a gas that pushes the bullet out of the barrel

Just look up "How bullets work". It is real simple, the firing pin strikes the primer which ignites the gun powder in the casing and the gases from that explosion propels the slug out of the barrel. You seem to have heard gases were what propelled the slug out of the barrel and forgot about what causes those gases, gun powder.

The short duration of the flash is what stops the action, as well as makes the subject + firearm visible in the photo.  Otherwise it'd just be a blurry mess.

If you'll notice; the guns are angled downward. Even though a 50 BMG has a ridiculous amount of punch power, chances are it's just digging a deeper hole. A bullet dropped from the same height as a parallel facing barrel at the same height will hit the ground at the same time a fired projectile will...just much closer to you. Unless you aim it in the air in a rainbow arc it's not going to go near the 1+ miles bullets warn you of on the boxes.
Ever wonder what that bullet hit? Hope there really is nothing out there.

Maybe you should change the title from "muzzle flash" to "bullet suspension" if that is your intention.  Either the title is misleading or you are using a tank to move a mouse.

@destinws2,
True, the bullet cannot be captured in suspended detail as it can in your method.  But since your video was primarily about capturing "muzzle flash", my simple method produces comparable results.

@j1fla 
Awesome, let me know how those bullet photos turn out.

@762girl 
My flash is a xenon tube. The reason xenon tube durations are high is because of the "quench".   The most ideal method is an arc gap a la Dr. Edgerton or Alan Sailer.  I stay away from that because it can kill you pretty easily.  Basically, I'm a chicken.

@lvachon 
Good idea and that would work for tight shots. It doesn't work for wide shots unless you have a REALLY big mirror.

Instead of a remote trigger for when your camera is downrange, put a mirror downrange and the put camera next to you.  Aim both the gun and the camera at the mirror and you can get nearly straight-on images of what looks like an incoming bullet.
Why you speak so many smart words?!?!?!  (LOL)

heee that was great!  I'm a 20+ year tac/def instructor and an ex-professional defense geek.  It was a Ruger .357mag prob SP-101 or whatever.  I Loved the well duhhh Mosfet part and btw another way is to shorten the strobe duration by using a higher voltage, lower capacity cap and the appropriate xenon tube (wink)  Also, if you can load using Blue Dot or 296, you'll get some pretty spectacular muzzle flashes!
GREAT JOB!

If you have a simple DSLR, all you need to do is mount it to a tripod, open the shutter in complete darkness,  and fire the gun.  The muzzle flash will provide its own illumination and all this other MacGyver equipment is completely unnecessary.  
As a gun enthusiast and an amateur photographer myself, I'm a fan of these vids, but no need here to pretend that an engineer is needed for what a mechanic can do.
